de.tub.pes.syscir.engine.util

Class CommandLineParser

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.tub.pes.syscir.engine.util.CommandLineParser

  • public class CommandLineParser
extends java.lang.Object
    Parses the string arguments of a method (i.e. string[] of any main method) for convenience. Returns a Map which maps every parameter used to the value.
    Author:
    Marcel Pockrandt

    • Field Summary

    • Field Detail

      • NO_SEPARATOR

        public static final java.lang.String NO_SEPARATOR
        Can be used if no separator is needed. Every element of args will be handled as a parameter.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • MINUS_SEPARATOR

        public static final java.lang.String MINUS_SEPARATOR
        Should be the standard separator. Every parameter starting with - will be handled as a new parameter with the following parameter as a value if not starting with a -.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Constructor Detail

      • CommandLineParser

        public CommandLineParser()

    • Method Detail

      • parseArgs

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> parseArgs(java.lang.String[] args,
                                                         int startIndex,
                                                         java.lang.String separatorChar)
        Parses a String array beginning at startIndex. The array should look like {-x, arg1, -t, arg2, -b}. The Method will return a Map which maps any String beginning with a separatorChar ("-" in the example) to either the next element of the array or to true if it doesn't exist or the next element also starts with the separatorChar. The resulting Map will look like {x=arg1, t=arg2, b="true"}.
        Parameters:
        args - String array to parse
        startIndex - index to start the parsing with
        separatorChar - character which begins every command line argument
        Returns:

      • parseArgs

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> parseArgs(java.lang.String[] args,
                                                         java.lang.String separatorChar)
        Parses a String array. The array should look like {-x, arg1, -t, arg2, -b}. The Method will return a Map which maps any String beginning with a separatorChar ("-" in the example) to either the next element of the array or to true if it doesn't exist or the next element also starts with the separatorChar. The resulting Map will look like {x=arg1, t=arg2, b="true"}.
        Parameters:
        args - String array to parse
        separatorChar - character which begins every command line argument
        Returns:

      • parseArgs

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> parseArgs(java.lang.String[] args,
                                                         int startIndex)
        Parses a String array beginning at startIndex. The array should look like {-x, arg1, -t, arg2, -b}. The Method will return a Map which maps any String beginning with a "-" to either the next element of the array or to true if it doesn't exist or the next element also starts with the separatorChar. The resulting Map will look like {x=arg1, t=arg2, b="true"}.
        Parameters:
        args - String array to parse
        startIndex - index to start the parsing with
        Returns:

      • parseArgs

        Parses a String array. The array should look like {-x, arg1, -t, arg2, -b}. The Method will return a Map which maps any String beginning with a "-" to either the next element of the array or to true if it doesn't exist or the next element also starts with the separatorChar. The resulting Map will look like {x=arg1, t=arg2, b="true"}.
